p.s: Within his 154 sonnetsShakespeare deals with the emotion of love from very different perspectives and writes about various aspects.
TroughThrough his work we get to know the importance of this topic for him personally but also the role it played in the society of the elizabethanElizabethan age.

While Sonnet 138 deals with trust as the fundament for a love and what truth means in a relationship, he also talks about the immortality of love in Sonnet 116 or makes a declaration of love on a beloved one by comparing to a summer's day in Sonnet 18.
Although many of his sonnets refer to a female beloved one, historians believe that some of his poetry might be dedicated to a male beloved one.
WetherWhether or not that is true it supports the modern perspective on love he had for his time, where the church and an absolutative state controlled society and formed the perception of the world.
WilliamShakespeare describes love not only as a bond between two people but as a construct that goes beyond.
As an object itself that alters infinitely and depends on the way people makes use of it.
This ideal of love thatShakespeare describes is the reason his work lost none of it'sits importance until today and puts his major impact on literature into perspective.
